page.lettertext:
fol.206r
[Nove]m
b
[.]Cecill
May it please yo
r
H. to advertise her
Ma
tie
that
e
18 of this moneth, I receaved her gratious l
re
of
e 4 w
t
an other to
e
States,
which according to
my charge, I presented unto them, in their pu-
blicke meeting, and accomplished as muche as
I was otherwise enjoined, by a verbal declara-
tion. But
M
r
Caron
sent them worde, above ten
dayes before,
at having had, as he related, com-
munication w
t
my
LL.
in case they would be
ready w
t
some succor of Shipping, against
e
Spanish preparation, her Ma
tie
would be plea-
sed, to let falle for a season, her poursuite for
remboursement. Wherat they joyed then excee-
dinglie, and reputed it expedient, to impart
e
tidinges out of hand, to
e
Provinces
abroade,
which was done w
t
expedition, to meete w
t
many
angers, which it seemed they feared; might growe
uppon
e soddaine, unles the people, by some meanes,
were put in better hart. But nowe I am instru-
cted by
e l
re
of yo
r
H. that in this there was an
error of too muche hast in M
r
Caron, before he
had receaved her Hig
es
resolution. Having
had among themselves some tyme of consultation,
upon
e l
re
and my demandes, they delivered me
an answear, w
t
speeches full of thankes, and dueti-
full acknowledgement of
e grace
at they receaved,
which could never
a
have
come, as they declared, in a
meeter season for their welfare. And touching
that which was required of
e aide they were to
yelde of 30 shippes of a certaine bourden, they
made no further question, but
at when it had bin
moved to
e States in particular, they would i
m
e-
diately take order,
at her Ma
tie
should be served, to
fol.206v
to her best contentation. But
for
e p
oint [of]
defraieng
e auxiliarie forces, they toke it a[lto-]
gether in
e self same nature, w
t
her form[er de-]
naunde: w
ch
could by no meanes be effected [but]
by
e Generalitie, to whome they found it [all the]
danger, To notifie
at her Ma
tie
will end [her]
Treatie w
t
e Contrey
. I have urged up[on it]
w
t
dyvers replies,
at
e people might be wonne [by]
their good endevors,
at it was not a thinge [to be]
stood on,
at
e su
m
e would be but smalle, y[et]
esteemed to be great, in regard of their w[illing-]
nesse, and
e manifold occasions
at pre[ssed]
her Hig
es
, and
e speeches
at would goe of [this]
negotiation, w
t
dyvers other reasons: to w[hich]
they gave no other answear, then they have [done]
heeretofore, but
at they meant to resume
e [mater]
againe, and to examine it throughlie, a[nd doe]
all
at they could to satisfie her Ma
tie
. [But]
as for me, I am persuaded, that they will n[ever]
yelde to any thinge, to howe little soever
e [summe]
be abridged, if it come to be demaunded, [as a]
debt already dewe, by expirati
o
of
e Tre[aty.]
For
at is
e place where they thinke they ar[.]
and
e people, they imagine, will by no me[anes]
endure it. For which I rest out of hope [of]
any better satisfaction, and to say w
at
I thi[nk,]
under humble correction, I hold it wholly [requisit]
to attend yet a while a fitter opportunitie, [which the]
State of thinges heere and tyme must prese[nt, or]
heereafter to project some suche forme of proc[eeding]
as may come neerer to their liking, and yet c[onclude]
e same effect w
t
at whiche is required.
They have secretly discoursed, about
e sending of [some]
fol.208r
persons to give her Ma
tie
more content, then hath bin
done by their answear delivered to me; and if it
chance to be resolved, it is lyke to be declared,
in their l
re
to her Ma
tie
wherof in lyke sorte, to
interpose my opinion, without note of presumpti
o
,
I should thinke
at suche a message would make
very muche for
e service of her Hig
es
for
at in
this case when they can not be persuaded, to assent
to her demande, both
e sending of their Deputies,
will seeme more respective in
e judgement of
e worlde, then their bare kinde of writing, and
it may be at their co
m
ing they will make some
fruitefull motion, or be wonne by good remon-
strance to recomend heere at home some speciall
purpose of her Ma
tie
or if neither of both should
happen, yet me thinkes in these sturres, and
turbulent tymes, where
e cause is so co
m
on be-
tweene
e two contreys, her Hig
es
cannot but
be holpen by
e conference, and counsaile, and
presence of suche persons, as I presume they
will depute. And where her Ma
tie
maketh
mention of
M
r
Barnevelts
ouverture, wherin
there was good hope both of this and greater
maters, I have moved him about it, and
debated it at length, but he putteth me in
mynde,
at
e tyme is farre other, and their State
more afflicted, and
at they have bin at
e
change, sins he and I talked of 20000
li
disbour-
sed to
e
F
r
Kinges
use, and at great expenses in
e field, where they had not then their armie,
at
e tyme of
at ouverture, nor yet in 3 moneths
after: and had perhaps, as he supposeth, if this
plotte had bin accepted, remained still in
garrison (withall he doth maintaine (as I
have formerly declared, to be
e opinion both
fol.208v
of him and of dyvers heere besydes)
at there is no po[ssi-]
bilitie to induce
e Co
m
on sort, to condescend to resitutio[n, by]
vertue of
e Contract, for
at they will not understand [it]
but as a mater of right, and a just stipulation, a[nd]
at it ought to be continued: for which of force th[ey]
must be wonne, by presenting unto them some oth[er]
forme of Treatie, w
t
some suche covenants and [con-]
dition, as may not charge her Ma
tie
, and yet tie [the]
Contrey to those paiments, which her Hig
es
wil[l]
require in regard of her dboursement
.
And heere I can not by
e way, but advertise yo
r
[H.]
at sins my last coming hither, I have found M[
r
]
Barnevelt farre out of temper, partly through
[e]
speeches of some of his Collegues w
ch
dislyke of hi[s dea-]
ling, as if his Ouverture to me, had bin a moti[ve]
to her Ma
tie
when she sawe
at of themselves, they w[ould]
yeeld to some good portion, to cast upon
em
e bour[den]
of a greater demande: wherew
t
they crushe him, as [he sai-]
eth very often, in their meetings: partly also he [is]
grieved w
t
somew
at
written out of
England
of
e op[inion]
and cunning, to winne time of her Ma
tie
. Whi[ch is]
also a touche to me in particular, in respect of [my credulitie,]
or some other kinde of weakenesse, in
at I could [not]
see
e pracise. But for my self, I could [wishe]
at
e mater then proposed, had
come
aswell in s[ome]
forme w
ch
her Ma
tie
could have lyked, as it w[as]
cleere and out of question,
at there was no diss[imula-]
tion. For as for any abuse
at Barnevelt co[uld]
offer, by
e meanes of his ouverture, it was so hard [for him]
to doe it, and so many must concurre, and it [had]
steede him so litle, as if
e circumstance of [thinges]
in
e nature of
at cause, and in
e forme of this g[o-]
vernement, and in
e maner of conferring an[d]
proceeding heere w
t
me, be duely weighed with all [his]
fol.207r
pointes, I doe not thinke to finde any,
at will stande
in
at opinion
. It is advertised hither from
very good place,
at
e Administrator of
Saxonie,
e
Elector of Mayence
,
e
archebishop of Saltsburghe
and
e rest
at are elected, to worke
e feate of Pa-
cification, have concluded among themselves, to
goe in hand w
t
at attempt, about Fe
b
next: w
ch
yet we thinke will be differed, till
e coming of
e
Archeduke,
who many men thinke will be longer
in coming because they say, he hath in Province
many yrons in
e fire, and is in hand w
t
Casot
e Consul of
Marseilles,
to deliver
at towne to
e
King of Spaine
. But for
e mater of Pacifica-
tion, this people is inabled by an excellent late token
of gods goodnesse unto them, to choake
e Enemie very
soundly, and to dashe
at practise altogether.
For there hath bin very happelie intercepted of late
in
e Mediterrane Sea, a special packet of l
re
s, w
ch
were written by
e
Marquis of Havrey
, and
Jo. Bap
ta
Taxis
, to
e K. of Spaine, and sent hither to
e States,
by
Mons
r
D'Esdignieres
. By
at of Taxis is disco-
ered a double a falsehood in their meaning,
both towardes
e
Empero
r
and
e States: and also
his lre otherwise is full of fraudulent courses.
They were written both in Cypher, and deciphred
in suche sorte, as I have sent yow
e transcript, by
Mons
r
de S
t
Aldegonde
: and were by
e States deli-
vered to me, w
t
an earnest request that they might
not be divulged, but to her Ma
tie
and my LL.
to
e end, in tyme convenient, they may serve
to be produced, to
e best advantage of their
purpose. Heere is secret notices
given, and as is thought, over true,
at
e
Co.
of Hohenlo
, who is nowe in
Germanie,
doth
fol.207v
imploy all his meanes to
e advancement of a [peace]
and is wholly busied among
e Princes, in
maters prejudiciall to
e State of this union:
all proceeding of dislyke betweene him and
Co.
Maurice
. Moreover it is reported,
at he w[ill]
meete
e
P. of Orenge
in his way to these Con[treis]
and w
at
his dealing may be
furt
further it [is]
feared of divers. It is undoubtedly [heere]
beleeved,
at there will be a truce between
S[pain]
and
France:
at
e least for a yere.
We have also heere intelligence,
at
e Gouv[er-]
nor of
Boullen
by
Calais,
hath suche doing[es]
of late w
t
e
D. D'Espernon
, as many men s[ee]
cause to doubt of his loialtie. As they [doe]
in lyke maner of
e holding out of Calais [which]
is not well provided, as
e Co
m
on voice go[eth]
and sith we heare
at de Fuentes maketh [great]
preparation, it is suspected of many,
at h[is]
dessigne is to besiege it. The [F.]
Kinge hath written to
e States, to knowe w[hat]
kinde of warre they will make
e next y[ere,]
whether offensive or deffensive, to
e end h[e may]
thereafter direct his owne affaires. An[d their]
answear thereunto, he desyreth to receav[e by]
his Ambassado
r
Mons
r
Buzanval
: to [whome]
he hath written to returne w
t
e same, a[nd to]
give him information of their state in [many]
maters. But I can not yet
well
per[ceave]
at
e States can well determine w
at
answ[ear to]
make as touching their warre. Som[e of]
those in these quarters,
at have best intellig[ence]
out of Spaine, give out for ce rtaine,
at
e b[rui-]
ted preparations, are nothing so great, a[s]
heere they did imagine. To co[me]
fol.209r
to
at last, w
ch
toucheth my self, I am to sue unto
yo
r
H. very humblie and earnestly, that her
Ma
tie
may be moved, to grant me licence to
returne: wherin before I went from home, my
L. T
re
r
promised to favor my petition, and I
hope my
L. of Essex
, will put his helping hand
to it. For I protest unto yo
r
H. if I might
have but
e leasure, to set some order in my
State, w
ch
is charged w
t
expences, more then most
men doe imagine, and is many waies wracked,
to my very great detriment, by reason of my jorneys
it would to me be all a mater, to live at home,
or abroade, either heere or wheresoever, as her
Ma
tie
may be pleased to thinke me fitte, to
serve her turne.
And so &c/
From
e Hage 26 N
o
95
.
